title: Just PyRosetta or also RosettaDL/Rosetta Licenses Needed
body:
Thanks for creating this amazing software.
I can’t find any exact guidance on which  modules are used precisely by BindCraft for commercial use - is it just PyRosetta, PyRosetta + Rosetta, or even PyRosetta + Rosetta + RosettaDL? They all seem to be licensed separately by UW and any guidance on which are actually needed is much appreciated.
author: LRParser

comments.body: PyRosetta is only licensed to Rosetta license holders so you would need both. RosettaDL is not used.

title: Design two binders simultaneously
body: Using the BindCraft, is it possible to simultaneously generate two binders binding to different interfaces on one target protein? I am thinking of running the pipeline twice, where you used the output complex from the first round as your target in the second round. Are there other ways?
author: riiichardh

comments.body: not two at a time, but you can use target+binder1 as input into a second round

Thanks so much, @martinpacesa! I will try this method anyway.

Now I have another issue. After binder hallucination and optimization, I can get satisfying trajectories with low i_pae (~0.2). But after passing through MPNNsol, the i_pae usually becomes quite large (~0.8+). I know that the binder sequence has been changed a little bit by MPNNsol, but why has the i_pae significantly deteriorated? Do you have some suggestions in this case?

title: RMSD weight
body: First of all, thank you for your excellent work. The community thrives because of you. When I was looking at your code, I was very interested in your filtering strategy, because we can't always find a suitable standard to filter the structures generated by AFD or RF+MPNN, so I carefully checked your weight file. I found that your weights for hotspot_RMSDhe Binder_RMSD are positive and usually large. Generally speaking, if the RMSD of the target structure in a trajectory is large, doesn't it mean that the prediction is not very reliable? The weight treatment in the code is a simple addition, so if the RMSD is large, will this cause the ranking of unreliable trajectories to rise?
author: astomer2

comments.body: Thank you for the kind works! I think you were looking at the filter json file, those are not weights but hard cutoffs of the value to filter against. In the case of RMSD it is the Calpha RMSD in Angstrom. "higher": false flag indicates that the value for the passing design should NOT be higher than that. In the case of Binder_RMSD it is to make sure that the binder in bound and unbound form does not have a radically different structure
You can apply different cutoffs if you wish, but these have been pretty generalisable so far for a variety of different targets

title: Difference between peptide_filters.json and filters_peptides.json
body: Hi, there are two files with a similar name in the settings_filters directory called `peptide_filters.json` (the last commit was "v1.2.0") and `filters_peptides.json` (the last commit was Add files via upload") where the only difference between them is the `peptide_filters.json` has `null` values for `Average_PackStat`, `1_PackStat`, and `2_PackStat` threshold values and `filters_peptides.json` has `0.35`.
author: ahmedselim2017

comments.body: Whoops, that's a leftover from previous version, will be removed

title: shutil.copy(best_model_pdb, design_paths["Rejected"])
body:
I got this error message after running my program. What could be causing it, and how should I fix it? Really looking forward to your help!




Fixing interface residues: B43,B63,B66,B69,B70,B73,B74,B77,B78,B80,B81,B82,B85
Base AF2 filters not passed for /home/BindCraft/example/PDL1_l91_s345674_mpnn1, skipping interface scoring
Unmet filter conditions for /home/BindCraft/example/PDL1_l91_s345674_mpnn2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/BindCraft/./bindcraft.py", line 411, in <module>
    shutil.copy(best_model_pdb, design_paths["Rejected"])
  File "/home/anaconda3/envs/BindCraft/lib/python3.10/shutil.py", line 417, in copy
    copyfile(src, dst, follow_symlinks=follow_symlinks)
  File "/home/anaconda3/envs/BindCraft/lib/python3.10/shutil.py", line 254, in copyfile
    with open(src, 'rb') as fsrc:
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/home/BindCraft/example/PDL1_l91_s345674_mpnn2_model2.pdb'
author: EHHDD2024

comments.body:
> Try updating the bindcraft.py file from the latest repo now.

Thank you so much! After updating bindcraft.py, it's now running smoothly. But I'm facing another issue now: why does bindcraft.py utilize all the GPUs when I run it? Is there a way to specify and use only a few GPUs?

It shouldn't. What if you add this line to bindcraft.py:

os.environ['CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES'] = '0'

title: Reading PDB residue numbers vs appearance order in PDB file?
body:
Hi,
  While picking hotspots for an uploaded pdb file, I came across an error that my picked hotspot residue actually doesn't exist.  I was using a PDB file where I pruned a large number of residues out of the system in order to make Bindcraft run faster.  The original pdb had ~400AA, and the new one had only 124, but those 124 still have the residue numbers from the original PDB file.  

My expected and desired behavior would be to use hotspot choices that are based on residue number in the pdb file rather than their appearance inside the uploaded PDB file.  I'm also not sure if the PDB fetching function has the same issue.

Here's part of the contents of my PDB file used:

> ATOM    598  N   ASP A 115     152.516 115.360  99.807  1.00 85.56           N  
ATOM    599  CA  ASP A 115     151.122 115.004 100.139  1.00 85.56           C  
ATOM    600  C   ASP A 115     150.714 115.453 101.556  1.00 85.56           C  
ATOM    601  O   ASP A 115     149.599 115.925 101.773  1.00 85.56           O  
ATOM    602  CB  ASP A 115     150.927 113.481 100.043  1.00 85.56           C  
ATOM    603  CG  ASP A 115     151.019 112.907  98.624  1.00 85.56           C  
ATOM    604  OD1 ASP A 115     150.553 113.580  97.679  1.00 85.56           O  
ATOM    605  OD2 ASP A 115     151.529 111.774  98.515  1.00 85.56           O1-
ATOM    606  H   ASP A 115     153.049 114.680  99.284  1.00 85.56           H  
ATOM    607  HA  ASP A 115     150.453 115.486  99.425  1.00 85.56           H  
ATOM    608  HB2 ASP A 115     149.939 113.237 100.431  1.00 85.56           H  
ATOM    609  HB3 ASP A 115     151.662 112.991 100.682  1.00 85.56           H  

Here is the hotspot from my JSON file:
> "hotspot":"A115,A185,A186,A187,A188,A189,A190,A349"

And here is the error when I run Bindcraft:
>[2024-10-24, 12:18:23 EDT] {EPI_bindcraft.py:127} INFO - AssertionError: ERROR: positions 115 and chain A not found

Is it possible to somehow change the pdb handling to match the PDB numbering more seamlessly?
author: TimCraigCGPS

comments.body: It should match the PDB numbering, so this is a bit strange. How did you do the trimming? Could you try to trim it again, for example in PyMOL or ChimeraX, save and try again?
I did it using pymol and "remove atoms" - I wonder if a partial AA would cause this...
most likely! I usually remove either in ChimeraX or manually via editing the .pdb file

title: Is there a way to restart where a previous run left off?
body: Let's say I ran the program and asked for 10 binders, and Bindcraft ended after 10.  Is there a way to go back and then ask for 100, but to start from where the previous one left off?
author: TimCraigCGPS

comments.body: Yes, you can just keep outputting to the same folder

Thanks, Martin. You are giving the right direction to solve this problem.
The protein is about 1000 amino acids. But I have defined the hot spot residues to be the first 100 amino acids.
I thought the software will only take it as a 100-aa-long target. But I could be wrong.
It takes the whole pdb you provide as input

title: How to resume the computation in the colab?
body:
I ran the computation to the 4th stage of "run BindCraft" . However, it was stopped because my computer went to sleep.

As such, I could not run the next step "consolidate and rank designs".

Is that anyway to resume the computation from where I left? Or I have to start over.

Thanks!

I am using colab pro+.
author: finexzhi

comments.body: Since the data is saved on your google drive, you can just start it again and as long as it points to the same output folder it will continue doing the designs. Note, the cosolidate and rank designs part will only start automatically once sufficient number of designs have passed the filters (100 by defualt). This can take a long time depending on your target size, generally you need to generate like 500-3000 trajectories to get 100 that pass the filters. However, if less is okay for you, then you can stop the design loop cell and just run consolidate and rank designs. You can also continue any time and consolidate again, the pipeline is designed in a way that you can always generate more designs and it does not "break" anything.

Thanks for the clarification. It is very clear now that the newly found hits were stored under the project folder. We can always run the software to search the sequence universe to find potentially better hits. I know this could be a random process. But when I start a new round of run, how can the software know which space it has already searched?
Based on the filename, that's why we include the binder length and seed number which is what in an oversimplified manner "roughly" determines the search space.

title: multiple target chains
body:
Hi

for the target_settings json. How can we specifiy multiple chains?

In PDL1 its only 1 chain:

> {
>     "design_path": "/content/drive/My Drive/BindCraft/PDL1/",
>     "binder_name": "PDL1",
>     "starting_pdb": "/content/bindcraft/example/PDL1.pdb",
>     **"chains": "A",**
>     "target_hotspot_residues": "56",
>     "lengths": [65, 150],
>     "number_of_final_designs": 100
> }

If my pdb is a complex, how can I specifiy that my target is chain B, C and D in json file?

Thank you in advance for your help,
JF
author: jflucier
